channel.title: Chee Wei Tan's Homepage
channel.description: Recent content on Chee Wei Tan's Homepage

item.title: Home Content
item.description: Dr. Tan received the M.A and Ph.D. degrees in Electrical Engineering from Princeton University. He was a Senior Fellow of the Institute for Pure and Applied Mathematics (IPAM) for the program on Science at Extreme Scales, and was a Postdoctoral Scholar in the NetLab Group at Caltech. His industrial experience includes consulting for Tencent AI Lab, Qualcomm R&D (QRC), Fraser Research Lab. His research interests are optimization of networks, distributed machine learning, cloud computing and AI.

Fu, Epidemic Source Detection in Contact Tracing Networks: Epidemic Centrality in Graphs and Message-Passing Algorithms, IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Signal Processing, 2021. S. Chen, P.-D. Yu, C. W. Tan and H.

item.title: Research
item.description: (1) Artificial Intelligence to Advance Health Informatics When the COVID-19 pandemic hit, the epidemic spread outpaced contact tracing efforts, leading to lockdowns and sufferings. Can Artificial Intelligence (AI) prevent the next epidemic, especially the more-deadly Disease X? Can AI-driven contact tracing strategies learn from past superspreading outbreaks to control future epidemics? To advance health informatics is one of the U.S. National Academy of Engineering Grand Challenges. In [1-4], we examine how network science, big data analytics and machine learning can address large-scale problems such as digital contact tracing and Infodemic management using COVID-19 data.

item.title: Short Introduction
item.description: Research interests are optimization of networks, distributed machine learning, cloud computing and AI.

item.title: Software and Openings
item.description: Ph.D. student openings: (1) Distributed machine learning and optimization (2) Artificial Intelligence technologies (e.g., AI chatbot, AI cloud computing) Candidates are expected to be proficient in mathematics (e.g., linear algebra, discrete math like graph theory) and have good software programming experience. Please email at cheewtan @ cityu.edu.hk with CV and transcripts. Automated Information Theory Inequality Prover (Software-as-a-Service to Interactively Prove Theorems) Software-as-a-Service Platform freely-available, and is now open-source (Github link in publication below).
